column23: role of leadership team near non-existent; little guidance or leadership
column27: No
column36: Amazed by how many "contributors" did nothing except put their name as author. To be honest, I wrote 75% of our group's section, and only 25% of the people regularly attended meetings and had a material impact on ideas/drafting. What a discouraging process... My impression is that with a few exceptions, (almost) no one really cares about the topic - they just wanted another pub
column49: The leadership team seemed to keep switching what they were looking for, so we had to go back and change things that we thought had already been settled. In the future, the leadership team should agree on an approach in advance.
column50: Unfortunately, so many participants had no interest in collaboration and sought ways to do the minimum necessary for inclusion as author. Shameful - makes me never want to work on a project like this in the future

column2: Conceptualizing first draft
column22: We didn't have enough people in our group- and the science and society section is by default of AGU a collection of leftovers with no real expertise and the group is the same. Passionate people but with no disciplinary background in science and society. I joined ICON to learn from mentors but instead I was the one with the most experience and I was not prepared to make the time commitment to take the leadership on.
column23: Science and Society needs help as a field- it is spread out without good theoretical foundation. Devote resources and people to create it an actual field instead of a leftover field for everything social that doesn't fit in with the biophysical sections

Perhaps coordinate groups for each AGU science domain that write review papers about the progress in that field in the last 10 years, and/or the most important challenges for the coming 10 years. I would love to contribute to such an activity (I am happy to talk further about this, if you are interested, gerbrand.koren@gmail.com)
column49:
A clearer description of the role and responsibility of the section champions. I contributed to several sections and noted a large difference in their behavior: in some cases they were really guiding the group, in other sections they were unresponsive in to communication or seemed only interested in securing the first author or corresponding author positions but not doing the actual work. 

I understand that people have different ways of leading an initiative, but I feel that it would have helped interactions between group members and section champions if there were clearer expectations (i.e. documented by the leadership team)
column50: I am considering to write a blog or short article about my experiences (both in terms of ICON in general and about the interactions between participants) from participating in 3 different teams (Biogeosciences, Atmospheric Sciences, Glob Env Change). Feel free to contact me about this if you would like to be involved or updated about this (gerbrand.koren@gmail.com)
